BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and gliding snow require caution. As a consequence of the snowfall the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase. Transportation routes situated at higher altitudes can be endangered in some localities in the regions with a lot of snow.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
20 to 30 cm of snow will fall above approximately 2000 m. The moderate wind has transported the new snow.
Dry and moist avalanches are possible as the day progresses, but they can be very large. Below approximately 2000 m medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large gliding avalanches and wet snow slides are possible. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant above approximately 1800 m. This applies in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
As before, it is inadvisable to engage in ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
90 to 120 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes. The new snow is deposited on bare ground over a wide area. This applies in particular on sunny slopes, as well as at low and intermediate altitudes. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
As a consequence of snowfall and the wind, the snow drift accumulations will increase in size. Up to 1400 m rain has fallen since yesterday. The sleet gave rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack over a wide area below approximately 1900 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Above approximately 1600 m snow will fall on Thursday. The danger will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs represent the main danger. Transportation routes situated at higher altitudes can be endangered in some localities in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
5 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 2000 m. The wind will be moderate.
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects and generally above the tree line. They are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
Shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack and natural avalanches serve as an alarm sign.
As a consequence of the snowfall dry and moist avalanches are to be expected, even large ones.
As before, it is inadvisable to engage in ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
60 to 100 cm of snow, and up to 110 cm in some localities, has fallen since Monday. A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on the soft surface of an old snowpack. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
Up to 1400 m rain has fallen since yesterday. The sleet will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack over a wide area below approximately 2200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of the ceasing of precipitation there will be a gradual decrease in the danger of dry and moist avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Evening drizzle or sleet. Avalanche danger progressively easing.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Snow cover rapidly settling and progressively consolidating. Triggering will be possible with low overload on many steep slopes at all aspects. To the south, the entire recent snow cover rests, almost entirely, on unfrozen uncovered ground, a condition that will favor accentuated snow flow phenomena. Natural avalanches both on the ground and on the surface of large dimensions will still be possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snow cover will progressively consolidate at all altitude ranges thanks to progressive clearings and night-time radiation. The thicknesses of recent new snow will settle rapidly, especially in the intermediate and valley bottom altitude bands. These areas will always be affected by snow flow phenomena, as the fresh snow will not be anchored to the thawed ground below. In the Alpine area, beyond the treeline, the expected weak ventilation will not particularly alter the surface layers, which will appear to be weakly cohesive, with considerable thicknesses. The connection with the old basal snow will improve, however crossing open, steep, leeward slopes is not recommended.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution. Backcountry touring calls for great restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Natural avalanches are possible, even large ones, especially on steep sunny slopes, as well as in steep rocky terrain. In steep gullies in the regions with a lot of snow the avalanches can reach intermediate altitudes. Even single backcountry tourers can release avalanches very easily, this applies even in case of a small load. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in steep terrain above the tree line. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, as well as at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain in particular at high altitude. The avalanche prone locations are prevalent and are difficult to recognise.
Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area over a wide area 60 to 120 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Monday above approximately 1500 m. The strong wind has transported a lot of snow. The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the wind slabs are very prone to triggering in all aspects at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will foster a gradual stabilisation of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution. Backcountry touring calls for great restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Natural avalanches are possible, even large ones, especially on steep sunny slopes, as well as in steep rocky terrain. In steep gullies in the regions with a lot of snow the avalanches can reach intermediate altitudes. Even single backcountry tourers can release avalanches very easily, this applies even in case of a small load. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in steep terrain above the tree line. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, as well as at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain in particular at high altitude. The avalanche prone locations are prevalent and are difficult to recognise.
Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area over a wide area 60 to 120 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Monday above approximately 1500 m. The strong wind has transported a lot of snow. The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the wind slabs are very prone to triggering in all aspects at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will foster a gradual stabilisation of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs represent the main danger. Backcountry touring calls for restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of, heavy snowfall and the moderate easterly wind, an unfavourable avalanche situation developed.
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant.
These avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and in the vicinity of peaks. They are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible.
Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
Natural avalanches:
Already in the early morning, dry and wet avalanches are possible. In the event of an overcast night this applies in particular. In particular from starting zones at higher altitudes large natural avalanches, capable of reaching a long way in some cases, must be expected in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 50 to 90 cm of snow has fallen since Sunday above approximately 2000 m. The easterly wind has transported some snow. A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes. The weather was cloudy. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large moist and wet avalanches have been released as a consequence of warming.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall on Friday. The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the often large wind slabs represent the main danger. The current avalanche situation calls for defensive route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all altitude zones. They are to be found in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, this also applies at a distance from ridgelines. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack and natural avalanches serve as an alarm sign.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation dry and moist avalanches are possible, but they can be large. The avalanche danger is within the uppermost range of danger level 3 (considerable).
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 40 to 80 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1600 m. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on the soft surface of an old snowpack. As a consequence of sharply rising temperatures and rain up to approximately 1400 m the snowpack could not consolidate.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger. Backcountry touring calls for a certain restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Natural avalanches are possible, even large ones, especially in steep rocky terrain, as well as adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls above the tree line. In steep gullies in the regions with a lot of snow the avalanches can reach low altitudes. Even single backcountry tourers can release avalanches easily. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, as well as at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain in particular at high altitude. The avalanche prone locations are prevalent and are difficult to recognise. Gliding avalanches are also to be expected.
Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 10 to 100 cm of snow has fallen since yesterday above approximately 2000 m. The moderate wind has transported some snow. The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the wind slabs are very prone to triggering in all aspects at intermediate and high altitudes. The snowpack will be in most cases moist. The high humditiy will give rise as the day progresses to thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The weather conditions gave rise to thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large moist and wet avalanches are possible. Gliding avalanches can also occur at any time. Single winter sport participants can release avalanches as before.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack remains wet all the way through over a wide area. In the regions exposed to rain this applies in particular.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs represent the main danger. Backcountry touring calls for restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of, snowfall and the light to moderate easterly wind, an unfavourable avalanche situation developed.
The wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant,, also on steep slopes. Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
Natural avalanches:
Dry and moist avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation. These weather conditions will bring about a weakening of the near-surface layers.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
30 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Sunday above approximately 2000 m. A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes. The easterly wind has transported the new snow.
Today on very steep shady slopes several medium-sized to large avalanches were triggered with explosives. Faceted weak layers exist in the old snowpack on steep shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall on Friday. The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The weather conditions gave rise to thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area. This applies in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large moist and wet avalanches are possible. Gliding avalanches can also occur at any time. The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects. In addition the precarious wind slabs should be taken into account.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack remains wet all the way through over a wide area. In the regions exposed to rain this applies in particular. Weak layers exist in the snowpack. The fresh snow of the last few days as well as the wind slabs remain for the foreseeable future prone to triggering.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Rapidly settling snowpack, with weak internal bonds. On the steep slopes at higher altitudes, releases and spontaneous releases of medium and large ground avalanches will be possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snow cover will progressively consolidate at all altitude ranges thanks to progressive clearings and night-time radiation. The thicknesses of recent new snow will settle rapidly, especially in the intermediate and valley bottom altitude bands. These areas will always be affected by snow flow phenomena, as the fresh snow will not be anchored to the thawed ground below. In the Alpine area, beyond the treeline, the expected weak ventilation will not particularly alter the surface layers, which will appear to be weakly cohesive, with considerable thicknesses. The connection with the old basal snow will improve, however crossing open, steep, leeward slopes is not recommended.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The large quantity of fresh snow and the wind slabs represent the main danger. Backcountry touring calls for caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of, snowfall and the light to moderate easterly wind, a precarious avalanche situation developed.
These weather conditions fostered a weakening of the near-surface layers in all aspects.
The cold fresh snow and the wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant, especially on steep slopes.
Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
Natural avalanches:
Wet loose snow avalanches are likely to occur, in the event of solar radiation especially on steep slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
30 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Sunday.
The easterly wind has transported some snow. Several medium-sized moist and wet avalanches have been released as a consequence of warming.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall on Friday. The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.
Weak layers in the old snowpack can still be released in very isolated cases by individual winter sport participants. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on west, north and east facing slopes above approximately 2400 m. Avalanches can in isolated cases penetrate deep layers and reach large size.

As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation more frequent medium-sized moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected below approximately 2600 m. In addition individual moist slab avalanches are possible. In particular in the regions with a lot of snow more frequent medium-sized gliding avalanches are to be expected, especially below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions up to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last two days. As a consequence of wind, avalanche prone wind slabs formed in the last few days, in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist deeper in the snowpack in particular on steep east, north and west facing slopes.

Up to high altitudes rain fell on Wednesday in some regions. Thursday: The surface of the snowpack cooled hardly at all during the overcast night and will soften quickly.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area 5 to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Friday. As a consequence of the new snow there will be only a slight increase in the avalanche danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Evening drizzle or sleet. Avalanche danger progressively easing.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Snow cover progressively settling and consolidating. The triggering will be possible even with a low overload, generating even large avalanches. Natural avalanche activity still possible from steep slopes not yet released, with medium-large sized phenomena.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snow cover will progressively consolidate at all altitude ranges thanks to progressive clearings and night-time radiation. The thicknesses of recent new snow will settle rapidly, especially in the intermediate and valley bottom altitude bands. These areas will always be affected by snow flow phenomena, as the fresh snow will not be anchored to the thawed ground below. In the Alpine area, beyond the treeline, the expected weak ventilation will not particularly alter the surface layers, which will appear to be weakly cohesive, with considerable thicknesses. The connection with the old basal snow will improve, however crossing open, steep, leeward slopes is not recommended.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs require caution. Wet and gliding snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs of the last few days can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. This applies especially adjacent to ridgelines. In some cases avalanches are medium-sized. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Avalanches can in very isolated cases be triggered in the old snowpack and reach large size in isolated cases in particular on very steep west, north and east facing slopes. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found above approximately 2400 m.

As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation more frequent moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, but they will be mostly small. On steep grassy slopes medium-sized gliding avalanches are to be expected, especially below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions 5 to 15 cm of snow fell on Tuesday. The southerly wind has transported the new snow. The more recent wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on steep shady slopes.

In isolated cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack, in particular on steep west, north and east facing slopes above approximately 2400 m.

The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m. The surface of the snowpack cooled hardly at all during the overcast night and will soften quickly.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall on Friday over a wide area, in particular on the Main Alpine Ridge and to the south. Gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are still possible.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Thin layers of snow resting on uncovered ground. Possible discharges of small and medium size on steep slopes at higher altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snow cover will progressively consolidate at all altitude ranges thanks to progressive clearings and night-time radiation. The thicknesses of recent new snow will settle rapidly, especially in the intermediate and valley bottom altitude bands. These areas will always be affected by snow flow phenomena, as the fresh snow will not be anchored to the thawed ground below. In the Alpine area, beyond the treeline, the expected weak ventilation will not particularly alter the surface layers, which will appear to be weakly cohesive, with considerable thicknesses. The connection with the old basal snow will improve, however crossing open, steep, leeward slopes is not recommended.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs above approximately 1800 m. Natural avalanches are the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Natural avalanches are possible above approximately 1800 m. This applies especially on steep slopes especially above approximately 1800 m, and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack remains subject to considerable local variations. Below approximately 1700 m hardly any snow is lying. The rain will give rise to rapid and thorough wetting of the old snowpack below approximately 1800 m. A lot of new snow above approximately 1800 m. The new snow and wind slabs of Thursday are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack in all aspects above approximately 1800 m. On steep slopes and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls the avalanche danger will increase during the day to level 2 (moderate).

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution. In addition individual gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on steep shady slopes at high altitude. Mostly avalanches are only small.

On steep grassy slopes mostly small gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind slabs are in isolated cases prone to triggering.

At low altitude hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall. As a consequence of the new snow there will be only a very slight increase in the avalanche danger.
